title: Doo dee doo.

Glo, dude, settle down.

[hr]Malvineous What, you mean like Linux? Or the thousands of other GPL/free software programs out there you legally don't have to pay for???
[hr]Or Keen mods, fangames, utilties?

[hr]Globox Would you walk into shop and steal their merchandise, just because it is 'released to the public'?
[hr]I can't stand hearing this argument. I pay for music, movies and software because I want a hard copy of the product. I pirate people's works like mad, and I will eventually buy the ones that I enjoyed.

Duplicating a work isn't stealing. Copying it and claiming it as either your own work or the genuine article is.

Oh, well. This kind of argument never leads anywhere, so I'll tell you this much. When I complete a game, or in fact any virtual work, that is worth selling, it'll be freely available to download from the Web, as well as in the form of a retail box that can be ordered online which can be freely copied and passed on to others.

It won't just be some empty shell of a box enclosing a CD, either. I'll put as much stuff in there as the scale of the game warrants (manuals, posters, etc), just like in the good old days when you could take pride in an off-the-shelf game you'd just purchased. The little extras are what make it all worthwhile, and the stupid thing about the industry's tendency to cut back on them is that they cost practically nothing.

In the meantime I'm going to behave as if that's how the industry works, regardless of how many bullshit measures they introduce to the contrary.

[hr]Globox Who gives a shit how much they want? They make the merchandise, they set the price. Get over it.
[hr]I'd be all for that, except that the musicians rarely set the price. It's the corporate money-grabbers that dictate how much we're meant to shell out, as well as how much of that goes to the artist. In my mind the real pirates are the publishers.
